revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist |name = Jack A. Apsche |image = Jack Apsche, Psychologist, WV Office, 7 Feb 2014.jpg |image_size = 265px |image_caption = |birth_date = {{Birth date|1947|9|23}} |birth_place = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] |death_date = {{death date and age|2014|10|12|1947|09|23|mf=y}} |death_place = [[Martinsburg, West Virginia]] |residence = [[Leesburg, Virginia]] |nationality = American |field = Psychologist |work_institution = [[Walden University (Minnesota)]], The Apsche Center for [[Mode Deactivation Therapy]] |alma_mater = [[University of Pittsburgh]], [[Temple University]] |known_for = his research and practice on adolescents with behavior problems |awards = 2008, Jan S. Handleman, Ph.D. Award |footnotes = |influences = [[Aaron A. Beck]], [[Marsha M. Linehan]] |website = }} ''' Jack A. Apsche ''' (September 23, 1947 - October 12, 2014) was an American [[psychologist]] who has focused his work on adolescents with behavior problems. Apsche was also an author, artist, presenter, consultant and lecturer.
==Background and education== Apsche was born in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]. In 1967 through 1968 Apsche served as a Helicopter [[Door Gunner]] with the First Cavalry Division [[Airmobile]] in the [[Vietnam War]] and he was highly decorated for his service. After returning from his service in Vietnam, Apsche attended the [[University of Pittsburgh]] where he graduated with honors with a B.A. in Speech, English, Political Science and a minor in Psychology in 1973. He continued his education at [[Temple University]], receiving an M.Ed, with an emphasis on psychological studies in education in 1977 and an Ed.D, in psychoeducational process and counselling psychology in 1986. While at Temple, Apsche edited The Effects of Punishment on Human Behavior.<ref>{{cite book | last1=Axelrod | first1=Saul | last2=Apsche | first2=Jack A. | title=The effects of punishment on human behavior | publisher=[[Academic Press]] | year=1982 | location=[[New York City]] | url=https://www.amazon.com/Effects-Punishment-Human-Behavior/dp/0120687402/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1384964893&sr=1-1&keywords=0120687402}}</ref> Apsche completed his post-doctoral internship at the Woodhaven Center at Temple University and his post-doctoral fellowship at the Joseph J. Peters Institute in Philadelphia.
== Career == Apsche is The Program Director for Forensic Psychology at the School of Psychology, College of Social and Behavioral Sciences at [[Walden University]], Minnesota and the Founder of The Apsche Center for [[Mode Deactivation Therapy]], also located in Virginia. Dr. Apsche is board certified in clinical child and adolescent psychology, clinical psychology, counseling psychology, cognitive and behavioral psychology, group psychology, couples and family psychology, and family psychology by the [[American Board of Professional Psychology]]. His primary research is in [[adolescent]] externalizing disorders.
Apsche is the developer of [[Mode Deactivation Therapy]] (MDT) an evidence-based [[psychotherapy]] technique to treat the complex interplay between trauma, [[Child abuse]], [[Personality disorder]] factors, [[Conduct disorder]], and a child's belief system that often lead to conduct problems such as aggression. MDT is a contextual behavior therapy, a type of [[psychotherapy]] that combines behavioral science with concepts of acceptance and [[mindfulness]], derived from eastern and western contemplative practices. MDT integrates methodologies from [[Mindfulness]], [[Cognitive behavioral therapy]], [[Acceptance and commitment therapy]], [[Dialectical behavior therapy]], and [[Functional analytic psychotherapy]], which are woven together with some key concepts that are unique to MDT methods. The most notable of these is the Validation, Clarification, and Redirection (VCR) methodology. VCR follows from the assessment and case conceptualization process steps and is aimed at validating the clients' past experiences, clarifying the resultant core beliefs, and redirecting behavioral responses that are caused by associated fear and coping mechanisms.<ref>{{cite journal | title=A literature review and analysis of Mode Deactivation Therapy | last=Apsche | first=Jack A. | journal=International Journal of Behavioral Consultation and Therapy | volume=6 | issue=4 | pages=296–340 | year=2010 | url=http://www.apschecenter.com/pdfs/Literature-Review-and-Analysis-of-MDT.pdf}}</ref>
===Teaching experience=== Apsche was an adjunct [[professor]] for psychological studies and criminal justice at his ''alma mater'', [[Temple University]], from 1990 to 1998 and an associate professor of psychology and counseling at [[Regent University]] in 2003. Apsche is a community clinical professor of psychology and behavioral science at [[Eastern Virginia Medical School]] and an adjunct professor of psychology at [[Fielding Graduate University]].
==Publications== Apsche is the principal author of the book titled "''Mode Deactivation Therapy for Aggression and Oppositional Behavior in Adolescents: An Integrative Methodology Using ACT, DBT, and CBT''".<ref>{{cite book | title=Mode Deactivation Therapy for aggression and oppositional behavior in adolescents: An integrative methodology using ACT, DBT, and CBT | first1=Jack A. | last1=Apsche | first2=DiMeo | last2=Lucia | publisher=New Harbinger | year=2012 | location=Oakland, CA | url=https://www.amazon.com/Deactivation-Aggression-Oppositional-Behavior-Adolescents-ebook/dp/B007W148LM/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1385016338&sr=1-1&keywords=apsche}}</ref> Apsche is the founding [[editor in chief|editor]] of the ''International Journal of Behavior Consultation and Therapy''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.baojournal.com/IJBCT/IJBCT-index.html |title=International Journal of Behavior Consultation and Therapy |publisher=Joseph D. Cautilli |location=Bala Cynwyd, PA |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927200153/http://www.baojournal.com/IJBCT/IJBCT-index.html |archivedate=September 27, 2013 }}</ref> He was a senior associate editor for the ''Behavior Analyst Today''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baojournal.com/BAO%20site/BAO-Index.html |title=Behavior Analyst Today |publisher=Joseph D. Cautilli |location=Bala Cynwyd, PA |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130812175714/http://baojournal.com/BAO%20site/BAO-Index.html |archivedate=2013-08-12 |df= }}</ref> Apsche also serves on the editorial board of ''Child Abuse & Neglect: The International Journal'' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.journals.elsevier.com/child-abuse-and-neglect |title=Child Abuse & Neglect |publisher=Elsevier | location=New York, NY}}</ref> and is a senior associate editor for the ''Journal of Behavioral Analysis of Offender and Victim Treatment and Prevention''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.baojournal.com/JOBA-OVTP/index.html |title=Journal of Behavioral Analysis of Offender and Victim Treatment and Prevention |publisher=Joseph D. Cautilli |location=Bala Cynwyd, PA |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130812190555/http://baojournal.com/JOBA-OVTP/index.html |archivedate=2013-08-12 |df= }}</ref>
Apsche has published several other books such as:
* ''Responsibility & Self-Management: A Client Workbook of Skills to Learn ''<ref>{{cite web|last1=Apsche |first1=Jack | last2=Jennings | first2=Jerry L. |url=http://bookstore.nearipress.org/index.php/responsibility-and-self-management-a-client-workbook-of-skills-to-learn.html |title=Responsibility & self-management: A client workbook of skills to learn |publisher=Neari Press | location=Fitchburg, MA | isbn=978-1-929657-29-2 | year=2007}}</ref> * ''Responsibility and Self-Management: A Clinician's Manual and Guide for Case Conceptualization'' <ref>{{cite web|last1=Apsche |first1=Jack | last2=Jennings | first2=Jerry L. |url=https://www.amazon.com/Responsibility-Self-Management-Clinicians-Manual-Conceptualization/dp/1929657285/ref=pd_bxgy_b_text_y |title=Responsibility and self-management A clinician's manual and guide for case Cconceptualization |publisher=Neari Press | location=Fitchburg, MA | isbn=978-1-929657-28-5 | year =2007}}</ref> * ''The Intimacy Manual: Balancing Control and Intimacy in the Bedroom and the Boardroom'' <ref>{{cite web| last1=Amidon | first1=Edmund J. | last2=Amidon | first2=Marilyn G. | last3=Apsche | first3=Jack A. | url=http://openlibrary.org/b/OL8449125M/The-Intimacy-Manual |title=The intimacy manual: Balancing control in the bedroom and the boardroom |publisher=International Information Association |isbn=978-0-945510-08-6 | year=2008}}</ref>
In addition, Apsche has published extensively in scientific journals and has appeared in many newspaper publications.
==Awards and honors== Apsche has won several awards for his research and clinical work, including The Jan S. Handleman, Ph.D. Award in 2008, and was nominated for the Distinguished Practitioner Award in 2008 from the [[Association for the Treatment of Sexual Abusers]] (ATSA) and Behavior Analyst Online's 2007 Article of the Year.
The International Academy of Behavioral Medicine, Counseling and Psychotherapy awarded Dr. Apsche a Diplomate in Professional Psychology in 2009, and a Diplomate in Chemical Dependency Counseling in 2010. Apsche is the only Psychologist who is board certified in six specialty areas by the [[American Board of Professional Psychology]].
==Forensic psychology== Apsche was an [[expert witness]] for the defense at the trial of serial killer [[Gary Heidnik]] and later profiled Heidnik in his book "''Inside the Mind of a Serial Killer''".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/probing-the-mind-of-a-serial-killer-jack-a-apsche/1001291747 |title=Inside the mind of a serial killer |publisher=ePrinted Books | year=2012 | location=Science Hill, KY}}</ref> In 2008, Apsche appeared in the [[Investigation Discovery]] program ''Escaped'', which described the experience of one of Heidnik's surviving victims, Josefina Rivera. While Heidnik was in prison, Apsche communicated with him, stating afterwards that in the more than 150 handwritten pages of letters he found the roots of a way to treat troubled youth in the killer's mind.<ref>{{cite web | last=Smith | first=Jordan | title=In killer's mind, counselor found the roots of a new way to treat troubled youth | url=https://articles.washingtonpost.com/2012-10-21/lifestyle/35502015_1_gary-heidnik-killer-cocaine-addiction | publisher=[[Washington Post]] | year=2012}}</ref> This provided the impetus for the development of the Mode Deactivation Therapy (MDT) methodology—a third wave therapy approach that proved effective to treat youth with complex behavioral problems and psychopathology.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Apsche | first1=Jack A. | last2=Bass | first2=Christopher K. | last3=DiMeo | first3=Lucia | title=Mode Deactivation Therapy (MDT) comprehensive meta-analysis | journal=The International Journal of Behavioral Consultation and Therapy | year=2010 | volume=7 | issue=1 | pages=47–54 | url=http://www.baojournal.com/BAO%20site/Craig%20Thomas%20Award--MDT-META.pdf | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130401052456/http://www.baojournal.com/BAO%20site/Craig%20Thomas%20Award--MDT-META.pdf | archivedate=2013-04-01 | df= }}</ref>
Apsche also provided expert testimony during the trials of serial murderers Harrison "Marty" Graham and [[Juan Covington]].
==See also== * [[Behavior Therapy]] * [[Cognitive Behavioral Therapy]] * [[Acceptance and Commitment Therapy]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
The '''Jadad scale''', sometimes known as '''Jadad scoring''' or the '''Oxford quality scoring system''', is a procedure to independently assess the methodological quality of a [[clinical trial]]. It is named after [[Colombia]]n physician [[Alex Jadad]] who in 1996 described a system for allocating the trial a score of between zero (very poor) and five (rigorous). It is the most widely used such assessment in the world, and as of 2017, its seminal paper has been cited in over 13000 scientific works.
==Description== The Jadad scale independently assesses the methodological quality of a [[clinical trial]] judging the effectiveness of [[Blind experiment|blinding]]. [[Alex Jadad|Alejandro "Alex" Jadad Bechara]], a Colombian physician who worked as a Research Fellow at the Oxford Pain Relief Unit, Nuffield Department of Anaesthetics, at the [[University of Oxford]] described the allocating trials a score of between zero (very poor) and five (rigorous) scale in an appendix to a 1996 paper.<ref name="jadad">{{cite journal| last= Jadad | first= A.R. | authorlink=Alejandro R. Jadad Bechara |author2=Moore R.A. |author3=Carroll D. |author4=Jenkinson C. |author5=Reynolds D.J.M. |author6=Gavaghan D.J. |author7=McQuay H.J. | title= Assessing the quality of reports of randomized clinical trials: Is blinding necessary? |journal= Controlled Clinical Trials|volume=17 |issue=1 |pages= 1–12| doi= 10.1016/0197-2456(95)00134-4| year= 1996 | pmid=8721797}}</ref> In a 2007 book Jadad described the randomised controlled trial as "one of the simplest, most powerful and revolutionary forms of research".<ref>{{cite book|last=Jadad|first=Alejandro R.|author2=Enkin, Murray |title=Randomized Controlled Trials: Questions, Answers and Musings| publisher=Blackwell| year=2007| edition=2nd| isbn=978-1-4051-3266-4}}</ref>
==Background== {{main|Randomised controlled trial}} Clinical trials are conducted for the purpose of collecting data on the efficacy of medical treatments.<ref name=chow>{{cite book|last=Chow|first=Shein-Chung|author2=Liu, Jen-pei|title=Design and Analysis of Clinical Trials|publisher=Wiley|year=2004|page=2|isbn=978-0-471-24985-6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HXMUEjZ4vyAC&pg=PA2}}</ref> The treatment might be, for example, a new [[drug]], a [[medical device]], a [[surgical procedure]], or a preventative regime.<ref name=chow/> [[Clinical trial protocol]]s vary considerably depending on the nature of the treatment under investigation,<ref>{{cite book|last=Brian |first=Everitt|author2=Pickles, Andrew|title=Statistical Aspects of the Design and Analysis of Clinical Trials|publisher=Imperial College Press|year=2004|page=5|isbn=978-1-86094-441-3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DMiH5y6SDuQC&printsec=PPA5}}</ref> but typically in a controlled trial researchers gather a group of volunteers and subject some to the test treatment, while giving the others either no treatment (known as a [[placebo]]), or an established treatment for comparison. After a defined time period, the patients in the test group are assessed for health improvements in comparison with the [[control group]].
However, trials can vary greatly in quality. Methodological errors such as poor [[Blind experiment|blinding]] or poor [[randomisation]] allow factors such as the [[placebo effect]] or [[selection bias]] to adversely affect the results of a trial.<ref name="Colditz">{{cite journal|last=Colditz|first=G.A.|author2=Miller J.N. |author3=Mosteller F. |year=1989|title=How study design affects outcomes in comparisons of therapy|journal=Statistics in Medicine | volume=8|issue=4|pages=441–454|doi=10.1002/sim.4780080408 | pmid = 2727468 }}</ref>
===Randomisation=== Randomisation is a process to remove potential distortion of statistical results arising from the manner in which the trial is conducted, in particular in the selection of subjects. Studies have indicated, for example, that nonrandomised trials are more likely to show a positive result for a new treatment than for an established conventional one.<ref name="Colditz"/>
===Blinding=== The importance of [[scientific control]]s to limit factors under test is well established. However, it is also important that none of those involved in a clinical trial, whether the researcher, the subject patient or any other involved parties, should allow their own prior expectations to affect reporting of results.<ref name="Day">{{cite journal|last=Day|first=Simon J |author2=Altman, Douglas G |title=Blinding in clinical trials and other studies|journal=British Medical Journal|volume=321|issue=7259|page=504|url=http://www.bmj.com/cgi/content/full/321/7259/504|pmid=10948038|year=2000|pmc=1118396|doi=10.1136/bmj.321.7259.504}}</ref> The [[placebo effect]] is known to be a confounding factor in trials; affecting the ability of both patients and doctors to report accurately on the clinical outcome. [[Blind experiment|Experimental blinding]] is a process to prevent [[bias]], both conscious and subconscious, skewing results.<ref name="Day"/>
Blinding frequently takes the form of a [[placebo]], an inactive dummy that is indistinguishable from the real treatment. Blinding can however be difficult to achieve in some trials,<ref name="Day" /> for example, [[surgery]] or [[physical therapy]]. Poor blinding can exaggerate the perceived effects of treatment, particularly if any such effects are small.<ref>{{cite journal | title=The revised CONSORT statement for reporting randomized trials: explanation and elaboration | journal=Annals of Internal Medicine | date=2001-04-17 | first=DG | last=Altman | first2=KF|last2=Schulz|first3=D|last3=Moher|first4=M|last4=Egger|first5=F|last5=Davidoff|first6=D|last6=Elbourne|first7=PC|last7=Gøtzsche|first8=T|last8=Lang|last9=CONSORT GROUP (Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials) | volume=134 | issue=8 |pages=663–694 | pmid=11304107 | doi=10.7326/0003-4819-134-8-200104170-00012 }}</ref> Blinding should be appropriate to the study, and is ideally [[Double-blind#Double-blind trials|double blind]], wherein neither the patient nor doctor is aware of whether they are in the control or test group, eliminating any such psychological effects from the study.
===Withdrawals and dropouts=== Withdrawals and [[dropping out|dropouts]] are those patients who fail to complete a course of treatment, or fail to report back on its outcome to the researchers. The reasons for doing so might be varied: the individuals may have moved away, abandoned the course of treatment, or died. Whatever the reason, the attrition rate can skew results of a study, particularly for those subjects who ceased treatment due to perceived inefficacy. In [[smoking cessation]] studies, for example, it is routine to consider all dropouts as failures.<ref> {{cite conference |vauthors=Lancaster T, Stead L | title = Dealing with drop-outs in clinical trials and meta-analyses |page=43 | conference = 7th Best Evidence Health Care Cochrane Colloquium | year = 1999 | location = Universita San Tommaso d'Aquino | url = http://gateway.nlm.nih.gov/MeetingAbstracts/ma?f=102184966.html }}</ref>
==Jadad questionnaire== A three-point questionnaire forms the basis for a Jadad score.<ref name="jadad"/> Each question was to be answered with either a ''yes'' or a ''no''. Each ''yes'' would score a single point, each ''no'' zero points; there were to be no fractional points. The Jadad team stated that they expected it should take no longer than ten minutes to score any individual paper. The questions were as follows: ''Was the study described as randomized?'', ''Was the study described as double blind?'' and ''Was there a description of withdrawals and dropouts?''<ref name="jadad"/>
To receive the corresponding point, an article should describe the number of withdrawals and dropouts, in each of the study groups, and the underlying reasons. Additional points were given if: ''The method of randomisation was described in the paper, and that method was appropriate.'' or ''The method of blinding was described, and it was appropriate.''<ref name="jadad"/>
Points would be ''deducted'' if: ''The method of randomisation was described, but was inappropriate.'' or ''The method of blinding was described, but was inappropriate.''<ref name="jadad"/>
A clinical trial could therefore receive a Jadad score of between zero and five. The Jadad scale is sometimes described as a five-point scale, though there are only three questions.
==Uses== The Jadad score may be used in a number of ways:
# To evaluate the general quality of medical research in a particular field.<ref name="Acupuncture">{{cite book|last=White|first=Adrian|author2=Ernst, Edzard|title=Acupuncture: A Scientific Appraisal|publisher=Elsevier |year=1999|page=109|isbn=978-0-7506-4163-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=e2KkvlQI7sYC&pg=PA109&lpg=PA109}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Wang|first=Gang|title=The quality of reporting of randomized controlled trials of traditional Chinese medicine|journal=Clinical Therapeutics|volume=29|issue=7|pages=1456–1467|doi=10.1016/j.clinthera.2007.07.023|year=2007|pmid=17825697|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Welk|first=B.|author2=Afshar, K. |author3=MacNeily, A.E. |title=Randomized controlled trials in pediatric urology: room for improvement|journal=J Urol|volume=176|issue=1|pages=306–310|doi=10.1016/S0022-5347(06)00560-X|year=2006|pmid=16753430}}</ref> # To set a minimum standard for the paper's results to be included in a [[meta analysis]]. A researcher conducting a [[systematic review]] for example might elect to exclude all papers on the topic with a Jadad score of 3 or less.<ref>{{cite book|last=Simon|first=Stephen D. |title=Statistical Evidence in Medical Trials: What Do the Data Really Tell Us?|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2006|page=122|isbn=978-0-19-856761-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zaq99M2p_sEC&pg=PA121}}</ref> # For critical analysis of an individual paper.
{{as of| 2008}}, the Jadad score was the most widely used such assessment in the world,<ref name="Clinical Epidemiology">{{cite book|last1=Hayes|first1=R.B.|last2=Sackett|first2=D.L.|last3=Guyatt|first3=G.H.|last4=Tugwell|first4=P.|title=Clinical Epidemiology|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|year=2005|page=31|isbn=978-0-7817-4524-6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cuvY6TItIwgC&pg=PA31}}</ref><ref name="scales">{{cite journal|last=Olivo |first=SA|author2=Macedo LG |author3=Gadotti IC |author4=Fuentes J |author5=Stanton T |author6=Magee DJ |year=2008|title=Scales to Assess the Quality of Randomized Controlled Trials : A Systematic Review|journal=Physical therapy|volume=88|issue=2|issn=0031-9023 |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb237/is_2_88/ai_n29412210/pg_1|doi=10.2522/ptj.20070147|pages=156–75|pmid=18073267}}</ref> and its seminal paper has been cited in over 3000 scientific works.
==Criticism== Critics have charged that the Jadad scale is flawed, being over-simplistic and placing too much emphasis on blinding,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Berger|first=V. W.|title=Is the Jadad Score the Proper Evaluation of Trials?|journal=[[J. Rheumatol.]]|volume=33|issue=8|pages=1710–1712|issn=0315-162X|url=http://www.jrheum.com/subscribers/06/08/1710-c.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080220154705/http://www.jrheum.com/subscribers/06/08/1710-c.html|archivedate=2008-02-20|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imbi.uni-freiburg.de/OJS/cca/index.php/cca/article/view/5053|title=Systematic Review of Quality Assessment Instruments for Randomized Control Trials|publisher=The Cochrane Collaboration|accessdate=2008-11-12}}</ref> and can show low consistency between different raters.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Clark |first=H.D.|date=Oct 1999|title=Assessing the quality of randomized trials: reliability of the Jadad scale|pages=448–52|journal=[[Controlled Clinical Trials]]|volume=20|issue=5 | pmid = 10503804|doi=10.1016/S0197-2456(99)00026-4|display-authors=etal}}</ref> Furthermore, it does not take into account [[allocation concealment]], viewed by The Cochrane Collaboration as paramount to avoid bias.<ref>Higgins JPT, Altman DG, Sterne JAC (editors). Chapter 8: Assessing risk of bias in included studies. In: Higgins JPT, Green S (editors). Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions Version 5.1.0 (updated March 2011). The Cochrane Collaboration, 2011. Available from www.cochrane-handbook.org.</ref>
==See also== * [[Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Clinical research]] [[Category:Clinical trials]] [[Category:Design of experiments]] [[Category:Scientific method]]

{{EngvarB|date=February 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox academic | honorific_prefix = Sir | name = John Fraser | honorific_suffix = [[Baronet|Bt]], [[Royal Victorian Order|KCVO]], [[Military Cross|MC]], [[FRSE]], [[FRCSEd]] | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = <!-- use only if different from full/othernames --> | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1885|03|23}} | birth_place = Tain, Rosshire, Scotland | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1947|12|01|1885|03|23}} | death_place = Edinburgh, Scotland | death_cause = | region = | nationality = British | citizenship = | residence = | other_names = | occupation = | period = | known_for = Establishing M. bovis as a cause of human TB. Fluid replacement in surgical shock. Ligation patent ductus arteriosus | title = Regius Professor of Clinical Surgery, University of Edinburgh. Principal, University of Edinburgh
| boards = | spouse = Agnes Govane Herald | children = | awards = <!--notable national level awards only--> | website = | education = Tain Royal Academy | alma_mater = University of Edinburgh | thesis_title = An aetiological and pathological study of tuberculosis of the bones and joints | thesis_url = | thesis_year = 1912 | school_tradition = | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | influences = <!--must be referenced from a third party source--> | era = | discipline = Surgeon | sub_discipline = <!--academic discipline specialist area – e.g. Sub-atomic research, 20th Century Danish specialist, Pauline research, Arcadian and Ugaritic specialist--> | workplaces = <!--full-time positions only, not student positions--> | doctoral_students = <!--only those with WP articles--> | notable_students = <!--only those with WP articles--> | main_interests = | notable_works = | notable_ideas = | influenced = <!--must be referenced from a third party source--> | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | footnotes = }}
Sir '''John Fraser''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|Bt|KCVO|MC|FRSE}} {{small|[[Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh|FRSEd]]}} (23 March 1885 – 1 December 1947) was [[Regius Chair of Clinical Surgery|Regius Professor of Clinical Surgery]] at Edinburgh University from 1925 to 1944 and served as principal of the [[University of Edinburgh]] from 1944 to 1947.
His study of [[tuberculosis]] in children was to disprove the view of the Nobel prize winner [[Robert Koch]] that bovine tuberculosis did not play a major pathogenic role in human disease. The subsequent legislation led to the elimination of tuberculosis from milk supplies and resulted in a decline in incidence of bone and joint tuberculosis in children. In 1940 he was the first surgeon in Britain to [[Ligature (medicine)|ligate]] an uninfected [[patent ductus arteriosus]].
==Early life and family== Fraser, whose parents both came from families of farmers, was born 23 March 1885 in [[Tain]], [[Rosshire]]. He was a few months old when his father died and he was raised as an only child by his mother.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/64773979|title=Surgeons' lives : Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh : an anthology of College Fellows over 500 years|last=|first=|date=2005|publisher=Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh|others=Macintyre, Iain M. C., MacLaren, Iain., Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh.|year=|isbn=0950362093|location=Edinburgh|pages=188–189|oclc=64773979}}</ref> He went on to attend [[Tain Royal Academy]].<ref name = "Graham">{{Cite journal|last=Graham|first=J. M.|date=March 1951|title=Sir John Fraser and his contributions to surgery|journal=Edinburgh Medical Journal|volume=58|issue=3|pages=105–124|issn=0367-1038|pmid=14840381}}</ref> He then studied medicine, gaining admission to the medical faculty at the [[University of Edinburgh]] in 1902, graduating [[Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery|MB ChB]] with honours in 1907, winning the Allan Fellowship in Clinical Medicine and the gold medal for Clinical Surgery.<ref name=":0" /><ref name = "Times">"Sir John Fraser", ''The Times'', 4 December 1947, p 6.</ref>
Fraser's son, Sir James Fraser, also became a surgeon and president of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh.<ref name=":1" />
==Early medical career== Fraser served as house surgeon, first in the [[Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh]] and then at the [[Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh|Royal Hospital for Sick Children]] under [[Sir Harold Stiles]], who was to have a powerful influence on Fraser's approach to surgical problems and scientific enquiry.<ref name="Graham"/> He became a fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh (FRCSEd) in 1910.<ref name="Times" />
Fraser's scientific approach was manifest in his [[Master of Surgery|ChM]] dissertation, nominally on inguinal hernia in childhood but containing a detailed account of the descent of the testis which was based on 1000 cases he studied and which contained many original observations.<ref>Fraser, J. ''The study of 1000 cases of oblique inguinal hernia occurring in children''. Thesis for the degree of ChM. University of Edinburgh, 1910.</ref> The dissertation was awarded the Lister Prize for surgery.<ref name=":0" />
==Research into tuberculosis== [[File:Edinburgh Medical School building, Teviot Place.jpg|thumb|Edinburgh Medical School, Teviot Place, seen in 2010]] For his [[Doctor of Medicine|MD]] thesis he studied the pathology and aetiology of tuberculosis of bones and joints.<ref name = "Times"/> As Stiles had treated bone and joint TB in children by radical excision there was a large pathological collection available for study. He set out to investigate the claim by [[Robert Koch]] that the risk of humans acquiring TB by drinking milk from tuberculous cows was negligible.<ref>R. Koch "The relations of human and bovine tuberculosis", ''[[JAMA (journal)|JAMA]]'', 51 (1908), pp. 1256-1258</ref><ref name=":Blevins">{{Cite journal|last=Blevins|first=Steve M.|last2=Bronze|first2=Michael S.|date=1 September 2010|title=Robert Koch and the ‘golden age’ of bacteriology|url=http://www.ijidonline.com/article/S1201-9712(10)02314-3/fulltext|journal=International Journal of Infectious Diseases|language=English|volume=14|issue=9|pages=e744–e751|doi=10.1016/j.ijid.2009.12.003|issn=1201-9712}}{{Subscription required}}</ref> This view was not supported by laboratory experiments commissioned by a British royal commission.<ref>''Royal Commission to Inquire into Effect of Food Derived from Tuberculous Animals on Human Health'', British Parliamentary Papers 1895 (C7703) xxxv; 1896 (C7992) xlvi</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dro.dur.ac.uk/10386/1/10386.pdf|title=Milk consumption and tuberculosis in Britain, 1850-1950.', in Order and disorder : the health implications of eating and drinking in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.|last=Atkins|first=P. J.|date=1999|website=Dro.dur.ac.uk|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2 April 2018}}</ref> Fraser disproved Koch's view<ref name="1928TBConference">{{cite book|title=Addresses ... Annual Mid-western Tuberculosis Conference ...|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hYZGAAAAMAAJ|year=1928|location=University of Wisconsin|page=82}}</ref> by demonstrating that 60% of the bones and joints he examined had the bovine form of the causative organism, ''[[Mycobacterium bovis]]''.<ref name=":0" /><ref>Fraser, J. "The pathology of tuberculosis in bones", ''Journal of Pathology and Bacteriology''. 1912;17:254</ref><ref>Fraser, J. "The relative prevalence of Human and Bovine types of Tubercule bacilli in bone and joint tuberculosis occurring in children", ''Journal of Experimental Medicine'', 1912;16:432</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://etheses.dur.ac.uk/4021/1/4021_1538.pdf|title=Tuberculosis: a Demographic Analysis and Social Study of Admissions to a Children's Sanatorium (1936-1954) in Stannington, Northumberland|last=Bernard|first=Marie-Catherine|date=2003|website=|publisher=Department of Archaeology, University of Durham|type=Ph.D. Thesis, Ustinov College|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> He went on to demonstrate the organism in local milk supplies and called for widespread [[pasteurisation]] of milk with increased regulation.<ref>Fraser, J. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2298919/ "A study of the types of organisms in a series of bone and joint tuberculosis in children"], ''British Medical Journal'', 1913;1:760.</ref> The subsequent legislation led to the elimination of tuberculosis from milk supplies and resulted in a decline in incidence of bone and joint tuberculosis in children.<ref name=":0" /> Fraser's 1912 MD thesis was awarded a gold medal.<ref>Fraser, J. ''An aetiological and pathological study of tuberculosis of the bones and joints''. Thesis for degree of MD University of Edinburgh. 1912</ref>
==First World War== [[File:Pages from Surgery at a Casualty Clearing Station, 1918.jpg|thumb|Pages from ''Surgery at a Casualty Clearing Station'' (1918), showing bullets and [[Shrapnel shell|shrapnel]],<ref>{{Cite web |url = https://archive.org/stream/surgeryatcasualt00wallrich#page/24/mode/2up|accessdate = 14 April 2018 | title = Surgery at a casualty clearing station}}</ref> the drawings for which were mostly prepared by Mrs Fraser.]] Fraser was commissioned in the [[Royal Army Medical Corps]] (RAMC) in August 1914.<ref name ="Graham"/> He served on the Western Front as Regimental Medical Officer in the [[1st Cavalry Division (United Kingdom)|First Cavalry Division]] and then, as surgeon to a [[casualty clearing station]], he treated the wounded from the [[Battle of Loos]]. In 1916 he was wounded, was [[mentioned in dispatches]] and received the [[Military Cross]].<ref name = Times/>
During this wartime service, he wrote papers on treatment of abdominal wounds, on the treatment of gas gangrene with Eusol (a solution of [[hypochlorous acid]])<ref name=":HypochlorousAcid">{{Cite journal|last=Fraser|first=J.|date=9 October 1915|title=The Value of Hypochlorous Acid in the Treatment of Gas Gangrene |journal=British Medical Journal|volume=2|issue=2858|pages=525–529|pmc=2303158|pmid=20767843}}</ref> and on shock and its treatment with gum saline and other intravenous infusions. His studies on blood pressure in shock resulted in his being invited to join the Medical Research Committee's small group on surgical shock whose other members included distinguished physiologists like [[Ernest Starling|E H Starling]], [[William Bayliss|W M Bayliss]] and the future Nobel laureates [[Charles Sherrington|C S Sherrington]] and [[Sir Henry Dale|Henry Dale]].<ref name=":Kloot">{{Cite journal|last=Van Der Kloot|first=William|date=2 June 2010|title=William Maddock Bayliss's Therapy for Wound Shock|url=https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/cd7d/2585cbc25c13f654c5e2a77e1d8b284a6dfe.pdf|journal=Notes and Records of the Royal Society|volume=64|pages=271–286|doi=10.1098/rsnr.2009.0068|via=}}</ref>
Fraser's wartime observations were a major contribution to this committee who were to pioneer the scientific basis of fluid replacement in surgical shock.<ref name=":Nature">{{Cite journal|date=23 February 1918|title=Nature and Treatment of Wound Shock and Allied Conditions|url=https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/article-abstract/217406|journal=JAMA: The Journal of the American Medical Association|language=en|volume=70|issue=8|doi=10.1001/jama.1918.02600080022008|issn=0002-9955}}{{Subscription required}}</ref>
While an army surgeon, he was successful in stitching up a gunshot wound of a heart.<ref name=":0" />
He produced a book with [[Cuthbert Wallace]] about his medical experiences during the war, ''Surgery at a Casualty Clearing Station'', which was published by A & C Black in 1918.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://livesonline.rcseng.ac.uk/biogs/E000228b.htm|title=Wallace, Sir Cuthbert Sidney – Biographical entry – Plarr's Lives of the Fellows Online|last=England|first=Royal College of Surgeons of|website=livesonline.rcseng.ac.uk|language=en-gb|access-date=2 April 2018}}</ref> Many of the illustrations were produced by Fraser's wife.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://archive.org/details/surgeryatcasualt00wallrich |title=Surgery at a Casualty Clearing Station |author=Wallace, Cuthbert; Fraser, John |year=1918 |publisher=A & C Black |accessdate=14 April 2018}}</ref>
==Post-war medical career== [[File:Royal Hospital For Sick Children, Sciennes.jpg|thumb|Royal Hospital For Sick Children, Sciennes, seen in 2011]] On his return to Edinburgh, he was appointed surgeon to the [[Royal Hospital for Sick Children, Edinburgh|Royal Hospital for Sick Children]] and the [[Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh|Royal Infirmary]]. In 1924 he was appointed to the Regius Chair of Clinical Surgery in succession to Sir Harold Stiles. He was elected a fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]] in 1928, his proposers being [[Arthur Logan Turner]], [[Harold Stiles]], Arthur Robinson, [[James Hartley Ashworth]] and Sir [[James Arthur Ewing]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783 – 2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp1.pdf}}</ref>
He chaired the Advisory Committee on Blood Transfusion which set up blood banks in Scotland in 1939.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/33820105|title=Portraits, paintings & busts in the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh|last=Edinburgh.|first=Royal College of Surgeons of|date=1995|publisher=The College|others=Masson, Alastair H. B. (Alastair Hugh Bailey)|year=|isbn=0950362042|location=Edinburgh|pages=70–72|oclc=33820105}}</ref>
Fraser's surgical career encompassed paediatric, abdominal, cardiothoracic and breast surgery and he wrote extensively on all of these.<ref name = "Graham"/> At a time when surgery on the heart was unthinkable, Fraser kept his interest in its possibility. On 19 October 1940 he became the first surgeon in the British Isles to successfully ligate an uninfected patent ductus arteriosus,<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite book|last1=Catford|first1=E.F.|title=The Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh|date=1984|publisher=Scottish Academic Press|location=Edinburgh|page=97|accessdate=}}</ref> two weeks after Oswald Tubbs had successfully ligated an infected ductus in London.<ref name=":Tubbs">{{Cite journal|last=Tubbs|first=Oswald S.|date=1 July 1944|title=The effect of ligation on infection of the patent ductus arteriosus|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/bjs.18003212502|journal=British Journal of Surgery|language=en|volume=32|issue=125|pages=1–12|doi=10.1002/bjs.18003212502|issn=1365-2168}}{{Subscription required}}</ref> [[Robert E. Gross (surgeon)|Robert Gross]] had performed the first in Boston in 1938.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gross|first=Robert|last2=Hubbard|first2=John|date=1939|title=Surgical Ligation of a Patent Ductus Arteriosus|url=http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?doi=10.1001/jama.1939.02800080049011|journal=Journal of the American Medical Association|language=en|volume=112|issue=8|pages=|doi=10.1001/jama.1939.02800080049011|issn=0002-9955|via=}}</ref><ref name="Fye2015">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w6SeBgAAQBAJ&pg=PT230|title=Caring for the Heart: Mayo Clinic and the Rise of Specialization|last=Fye|first=W. Bruce|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2015|isbn=978-0-19-998237-0|location=|publication-place=United States|page=230|pages=}}</ref> Before retiring from surgery Fraser operated on 12 such cases.<ref name="Graham"/> In addition, he had performed left cervical [[sympathectomy]] for [[angina]]. His experience with O'Shaughnessy's cardio-omentopexy surgery was less successful.<ref name=":0" />
In October 1944 he was appointed principal of the University of Edinburgh.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ourhistory.is.ed.ac.uk/index.php/Sir_John_Fraser_(1885-1947)|title=Sir John Fraser (1885–1947)|website=ourhistory.is.ed.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=31 March 2018}}</ref> He was regarded as a major contributor of the golden age for Edinburgh surgery.<ref name=":0" />
==Death and legacy== The workload strain of the [[Second World War]] contributed to his deteriorating health, and following his guided smooth transition of the university from war time to peacetime, Sir John Fraser died in Edinburgh on 1 December 1947.<ref name="Times" /> <!-- Fraser House (now renamed Holland House) and Fraser Court at [[Pollock Halls of Residence]] were named after him.{{citation required|date=April 2018}}-->
==Honours== The [[Freedom of the City|Freedom]] of Tain was conferred upon Fraser in 1925.<ref name="Herald Death">{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9GdAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kJQMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3387%2C4979587 |title=Sir John Fraser Dead |work=The Glasgow Herald |page=4 |date=2 December 1947 |accessdate=1 April 2018}}</ref> He was awarded an Honorary Fellowship by the American College of Surgeons in 1926.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/49197252|title=A century of international progress and tradition in surgery : an illustrated history of the International Society of Surgery|last=Liebermann-Meffert|first=Dorothea|date=2001|publisher=Kaden|others=White, Harvey.|year=|isbn=3922777422|location=Heidelberg|pages=210|oclc=49197252}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.facs.org/about-acs/archives/acshistory/honoraryfellows|title=Honorary Fellows of the American College of Surgeons|website=American College of Surgeons|language=en|access-date=11 February 2018}}</ref>
He was Surgeon to the King in Scotland, and was created a Knight Commander of the Victorian Order (KCVO) in 1937.<ref name="Times" /> In the [[1943 Birthday Honours]] he was made a Baronet with the creation of the [[Fraser baronets#Fraser baronets, of Tain (1943)|Fraser Baronetcy, of Tain]] in the County of Ross.<ref name="Graham" /> He was awarded the honorary degree of LL.D. by the University of Edinburgh in 1944.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2C41AAAAIBAJ&sjid=A6YLAAAAIBAJ&pg=4087%2C2403195 |title=LL.D. for Sir John Fraser |work=The Glasgow Herald |date=15 June 1944 |page=2 |accessdate=24 December 2017}}</ref>
{{s-start}} {{succession box | before=[[Thomas Henry Holland]] | title=[[Edinburgh University Principals|Principals of Edinburgh University]] | years=1944–1948 | after=[[Edward Victor Appleton]]}} {{s-end}}
==Selected publications== * ''[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.b5193862;view=1up;seq=9 Tuberculosis of the bones and joints in children]''. London: A & C Black, 1914. * ''[https://archive.org/details/surgeryatcasualt00wallrich Surgery at a Casualty Clearing Station]'' (with Cuthbert Wallace). London: A & C Black, 1918. * ''Surgery of Childhood''. London: Arnold & Co, 1926.
==References== {{Reflist}} {{authority control}}

revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=June 2015}} {{Orphan|date=January 2011}}
'''Kids for World Health''' ('''KFWH''') aims to cover all aspects of the control and elimination of [[African trypanosomiasis|Sleeping Sickness]], [[Trypanosomiasis]], [[Buruli Ulcer]], [[Chagas Disease]], and [[Leishmaniasis]]/[[Kala Azar]].<ref name="kfwh">{{cite web|url=http://kfwh.org/|title=http://kfwh.org/|publisher=kfwh.org|accessdate=2014-05-13}}</ref><ref name="kfwh2">{{cite web|url=http://kfwh.org/missionstatement.asp|title=missionstatement|publisher=kfwh.org|accessdate=2014-05-13}}</ref> Kids For World Health's motto is "Life is important for all people, rich or poor."
== History ==
Kids for World Health was founded in 2001 at [[Chatsworth Avenue School]], in [[Larchmont, New York]] by a then 3rd grade class who were motivated after watching a CBS film from "[[60 Minutes]]" on the [[Southern Sudan]] [[African trypanosomiasis|Sleeping Sickness]] Program in 1994. In the beginning, the class of 18 wrote many letters to pharmaceutical companies, contacted the [[United Nations]], contacted the [[World Health Organization]], and studied the research and materials from [[Doctors Without Borders]]. They met with the CEO of [[Bristol Meyers Squibb]], and scheduled a trip to [[Washington D.C.]] to lobby for [[Ethnic groups of Africa|African]] families to have access to drugs.<ref name="kfwh3">{{cite web|url=http://kfwh.org/history.asp|title=history|publisher=kfwh.org|accessdate=2014-05-13}}</ref>
== Actions to date ==
KFWH Actions to date (April, 2009):<ref name="kfwhtrek.org">{{cite web|url=http://kfwhtrek.org/3.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726215924/http://kfwhtrek.org/3.html |archive-date=2011-07-26 |dead-url=yes|title=KFWH Actions - Kids for World Health|author=1&1 WebsiteBuilder|accessdate=2014-05-13}}</ref> * Construction of the first KFWH Pediatric Wing in the region of [[Yei, Sudan]] servicing 90 villages. * Funding of educational materials on prevention of [[Neglected Tropical Diseases]] for villagers in Tambora County, Sudan. * Construction of a fully equipped kitchen for a hospital in [[Yei, Sudan]]. * Construction of an equipped laboratory within a clinic in [[Yei, Sudan]]. * Funding for training of doctors and assistants in [[Lisbon, Portugal]]. * Construction of a second KFWH Pediatric Wing in Duk County, Sudan servicing 150,000 villagers. * Construction of a third KFWH Pediatric Wing in Kaliua, Tanzania servicing 250,000 villagers. * Construction of a fourth KFWH Pediatric Wing at the Lwala Hospital in Otuboi Sub County, Uganda for the treatment of [[African trypanosomiasis|Sleeping Sickness]] and [[Malaria]], servicing 25,000 villagers. * Support of the John Bul Dau Clinic and KFWH Treatment Room in Duk County, Sudan for the treatment of Neglected Tropical Diseases.<ref name="kfwhtrek.org"/><ref name="johndaufoundation">{{cite web|url=http://www.johndaufoundation.org/index.html|title=John Dau Foundation|publisher=johndaufoundation.org|accessdate=2014-05-13}}</ref>
== External links == * [http://kfwh.org/ The official Kids for World Health website] * [http://kfwhtrek.org/ The official Kids for World Health Hike-a-Thon: Trek for Treatment website]
== Newspaper Articles == * [http://www.voanews.com/english/archive/2003-05/a-2003-05-15-59-Neglected.cfm?moddate=2003-05-15 "Exhibits - Access EXPO in Washington, DC", "Neglected Diseases Kill 14 Million People A Year". Doctors without Borders with Kids for World Health at Washington D.C. Expo (2003)] * [http://doctorswithoutborders.org/events/exhibits/expo/delivery.cfm Photo Gallery of "Exhibits - Access EXPO in Washington, DC", "Neglected Diseases Kill 14 Million People A Year". Doctors without Borders with Kids for World Health at Washington D.C. Expo (2003)] * [http://www.larchmontgazette.com/2005/articles/20050324hommockskids.html "Local Kids Impact World Health: Expo Highlights Efforts" (2005)] * [http://the-medical-dictionary.com/american_trypanosomiasis_article_4.htm "Wake-up call: an alarming TV program about sleeping sickness spurred a group of students into action" (2005)] * [http://www.larchmontgazette.com/2006/articles/20060228kidsforworldhealth.html "Murray Kids Learn: 'You CAN make a difference'" (2006)] * [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/20/nyregion/nyregionspecial2/20noticedwe.html?_r=1 "9th Graders Reach Out to Sudan, With Cash" (2007)] * [http://www.larchmontgazette.com/2008/articles/20080515kfwhlowey.html "Kids for World Health Lobbies Congresswoman Lowey" (2008)] * [http://www.larchmontgazette.com/?p=4039 "KFWH Trekkers Raise $4000 for African Clinic" (2009)] * [http://www.larchmontgazette.com/news/mother-jackson-kids-for-world-health-win-mlking-awards/ "Mother Jackson & Kids for World Health Win MLKing Awards" (2009)] * [http://www.larchmontgazette.com/news/senator-andrea-stewart-cousins-to-address-mlking-celebration/ "Stewart-Cousins to Address MLKing Celebration" (2010)] * [http://www.larchmontgazette.com/news/help-haiti-boost-human-rights-twin-themes-at-mlk-event/ "Help Haiti, Boost Human Rights: Twin Themes at MLK Event" (2010)] * [http://www.lohud.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=20101310315 "Third graders' cause grows into help for 1 million Africans" (2010)]

In episodes with multiple [[patient]]s, or multiple diagnoses, each diagnosis is given a separate entry for sorting. trypanosomiasis]] |- | style= "background: #D8D8D8;" |1 | 8 | [[Phosdrin]] poisoning |- | style= "background: #D8D8D8;" |1 | 9 | [[Arteriovenous malformation]] |- | style= "background: #D8D8D8;" |1 | [[Munchausen syndrome]] |- | 2 | 10 | [[Bipolar disorder]] and [[Cerebral malaria]] |- | 2 | 11 | [[Ritalin]] abuse and [[hepatocellular adenoma]] |- | 2 | 12 | [[Serotonin syndrome]] |- | 2 | 13 | revision.text:
'''Lucien Muhlfeld''' ([[Paris]], 4 August 1870 – Paris, 1 December 1902) was a French novelist and dramatic critic.
After completing his studies at the [[Lycée Condorcet]], Muhlfeld entered the [[University of Paris]], where he took the licentiate degrees in literature and law. He then engaged in literary work as a contributor to various periodicals. He became successively dramatic critic for ''[[L'Écho de Paris]]'', ''[[La Revue Blanche]]'', and the ''Revue d'Art Dramatique''.
From 1890 to 1895 he was assistant librarian at the University of Paris; but he gave up that position to devote himself entirely to literature. He died prematurely of [[typhoid fever]] after eating contaminated oysters.
He was the author of ''Le Mauvais Désir'' (1890), ''La Carrière d'André Tourette'' (1900), and ''L'Associée'' (1902)—all three novels dealing with Parisian life.
His two critical works, ''La Fin d'un art'' (1890) and ''Le monde où l'on imprime'' (1897), never became popular.
He wrote also (with [[Pierre Veber]]) a one-act play entitled ''Dix ans après'' (produced at the [[Odéon]] in 1897).
==Works== * ''Le Mauvais Désir'' (1890) * ''La Carrière d'André Tourette'' (1900) * ''L'Associée'' (1902) * ''La Fin d'un art'' (1890) * ''Le monde où l'on imprime'' (1897) * ''Dix ans après'' (with Pierre Veber, 1897).
{{Authority control}}

page.title: National Registry of Food Safety Professionals

revision.comment: /* See also */ Update on new ownership.
revision.text:
[[Image:National_Registry_of_Food_Safety_Professionals_logo.jpg|thumb|National Registry of Food Safety Professionals logo]]
'''National Registry of Food Safety Professionals (NRFSP)''' is a [[food safety]] certification for the [[restaurant]], [[hotel]], and [[quick service restaurant|quick service]] industry business administered by Environmental Health Testing. NRFSP was founded in 1998 through partnerships between the [[Chartered Institute of Environmental Health]] and Professional Testing, Inc. and is headquartered in [[Orlando, Florida]].{{cn|date=September 2015}}
NRFSP's International Certified Food Safety Manager is the first and only food manager safety certification to be accredited by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) based on the ANSI/[[ISO/IEC 17024]] standard for conformity - general requirement for bodies operating certification of persons.<ref name="PR Newswire">[http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/national-registry-of-food-safety-professionals-becomes-first-food-safety-manager-certification-program-to-earn-ansi-accreditation-based-on-iso-standard-136586123.html] PR Newswire</ref><ref name="ANSI/ISO/IEC 17024 (Accredited)">[https://www.ansica.org/wwwversion2/outside/ALLdirectoryListing.asp?menuID=2&prgID=201&status=4 ANSI/ISO/IEC 17024 (Accredited)]</ref> NRFSP’s certification program has been developed to assess the knowledge of entry-level Food Safety Managers in the retail food industry.
The Food Safety Manager examination is acceptable in all states and jurisdictions that recognize those standards set by the Conference for Food Protection and is an assurance of quality in the development and maintenance of the exams.
NRFSP runs the Food Safety blog [http://www.foodsafetyspot.com Food Safety Spot].
Lawrence Lynch is President and CEO of National Registry of Food Safety Professionals.
==See also== *[[Chartered Institute of Environmental Health]] (United Kingdom), Chartered Institute no longer owns Nation Registry of Food Safety Professionals. National Registry of Food Safety Professionals was bought by the National Restaurant Association as reported in Nations Restaurant News on February 10, 2016, by Brent Thorn. <ref>"National Restaurant News", 2/10/2016</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://nrfsp.com National Registry of Food Safety Professionals] *[http://envhealthtesting.com Environmental Health Testing]

[[File:Pioneers For A Cure logo.jpg|thumb|Pioneers For A Cure logo]] [[Image:Am Yisrael Chai CD.jpg|thumb|alt=CD cover of 'Am Yisrael Chai'.|CD cover of 'Am Yisrael Chai.']] [[File:Mira-Sasson.jpg|thumb|Israeli artist [[Mira Sasson]]]]
'''Pioneers For A Cure - Songs To Fight Cancer''' was started in 2008 to raise funds in support of organizations pioneering new methods of cancer treatment and research. Pioneers For A Cure is the largest showcase of cancer charities on the web. Called '[A] stellar model of artist-driven grassroots philanthropy' by [[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]], the non-profit project records [[public domain]] songs, reinterpreted by contemporary artists and made available on the organization's website. for downloading for a modest donation. Over 100 songs have been recorded by dozens of artists from around the world including [[Suzanne Vega]], [[Ben E. King]], [[Tom Chapin]], [[Tom Verlaine]], [[Matt White (musician)|Matt White]] and [[David Broza]]. Proceeds from song downloads are donated to artist-selected cancer charities such as the [[American Cancer Society]], [[St. Jude Children's Hospital]], the [[Breast Cancer Research Foundation]], and [[Susan G. Komen for the Cure]]. Pioneers For A Cure is sponsored by Joodayoh, Inc., a [[501(c)3]] organization
==History== The organization began with ‘The Postcard Project,’<ref name="nat_geo">{{cite web|url=http://worldmusic.nationalgeographic.com/view/page.basic/article/content.article/pioneers_for_cure/en_US|title=National Geographic: Images of Animals, Nature, and Cultures|work=nationalgeographic.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100617162014/http://worldmusic.nationalgeographic.com/view/page.basic/article/content.article/pioneers_for_cure/en_US|archivedate=2010-06-17|df=}}</ref> gathering many Jewish musical artists to record the music of the pioneers of [[Israel]] (The [[Aliyah|Chalutzim]]).<ref name="forward">{{cite web|url=http://www.forward.com/articles/108422/|title=Pioneer Songs, Revisited|date=24 June 2009|work=The Forward}}</ref><ref name="jpost">{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Home/Article.aspx?id=145588|title=Pioneering a cure|work=The Jerusalem Post - JPost.com}}</ref> The songs were then posted on the Pioneers For A Cure website, where users make [[micro-donations]]<ref name="sing_out">[http://singout.wordpress.com/2009/12/03/pioneers-for-a-cure/ Sing Out! News Service] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100624021404/http://singout.wordpress.com/2009/12/03/pioneers-for-a-cure/ |date=2010-06-24 }}</ref> to artist-selected cancer charities and receive song downloads in return.
‘The Postcard Project’ was inspired by the postcards used to disseminate the music of the Chalutzim in the years preceding the creation of the modern state of Israel.<ref name="njjn">{{cite web|url=http://njjewishnews.com/njjn.com/050709/njArtistsPutTheirStamps.html|title=Artists put their stamps on Israeli folk tradition|work=njjewishnews.com}}</ref> In an attempt to create a cultural base, composers were commissioned by the [[Keren Kayemet]] (now also known as The [[Jewish National Fund]]) to write new folk music, a soundtrack to the formation of the nation. The words and melodies were printed on postcards, which were mailed across [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]], [[Europe]], and [[Asia Minor]].<ref name="pioneer_producer_blog">{{cite web|url=http://pioneerproducer.blogspot.com/2009/02/postcards-from-edge.html|title=PioneerProducer|author=GW|work=pioneerproducer.blogspot.com}}</ref>
‘The Israel Sessions’ is a more recent project of PFAC, featuring 16 songs recorded in Israel by producer [[Hasidic New Wave|Greg Wall]] and engineer Dave Richards in August, 2009.<ref name="ynet">{{cite web|url=http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3786854,00.html|title=ynet שירי חלוצים חודשו לטובת המאבק בסרטן - מעורבות|work=ynet}}</ref> In addition, several songs have been recorded for the forthcoming ‘American Sessions,’ featuring classic American songs by popular artists.
In 2009, Pioneers released the single [[Shlomo Carlebach|“Am Yisrael Chai]],”<ref name="nat_geo" /> featuring over 40 performers, edited by [[Keith Olsen]] and mixed by [[Bob Clearmountain]].
The Pioneers For A Cure organization includes Music Producer Greg Wall, Executive Producer Beth Ravin, Chief Recording Engineer Dave Richards, artist [[Mira Sasson]] and Joodayoh, Inc. Executive Director Ricky Orbach.
In January 2011 Pioneers For A cure launched its new website,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pioneersforacure.org/|title=Songs to Fight Cancer - Pioneers for a Cure|work=pioneersforacure.org}}</ref> enabling donations to cancer charities. Website design and development by WhiteLabel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whitelabel.co.il/|title=קידום אתרים, שיווק באינטרנט - WhiteLabel|work=whitelabel.co.il}}</ref>
On October 17, 2011, The Huffington Post featured an interview with Suzanne Vega in which the singer discusses her work with Pioneers For A Cure.<ref name="huffpo">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mike-ragogna/stevie-nicks-moonlight-a_b_1014756.html|title=Stevie Nicks' "Moonlight (A Vampire's Dream)," Plus Chatting With Tori Amos, Suzanne Vega, Jackie DeShannon and Shelby Lynne|work=The Huffington Post}}</ref>
==The Pioneer Portraits== Israeli artist [[Mira Sasson]] has painted portraits of dozens of the Pioneers For A Cure artists, including [[Ben E. King]], [[The Klezmatics|Lorin Sklamberg]], [[David Broza]], [[Basya Schechter]], [[Neshama Carlebach]], [[Noah Solomon]], [[Tovah Feldshuh]], and [[Dudu Fisher]].
Sasson was born in 1965 in Bnei-Brak, Israel, and began drawing and painting as a child. In addition to other work, Sasson has illustrated and authored several children’s books published in Israel. The books are currently being translated for publishing in the United States.<ref name="mira_sasson">{{cite web|url=http://www.newsjunkyjournal.com/mira-sassons-pioneer-portraits-now-available-as-us-postage-to-fight-cancer/2518052/ |title=News Junky Journal |work=newsjunkyjournal.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331144135/http://www.newsjunkyjournal.com/mira-sassons-pioneer-portraits-now-available-as-us-postage-to-fight-cancer/2518052/ |archivedate=March 31, 2012 }}</ref>
==Pioneers For A Cure Award Gala== On November 22, 2009, Pioneers For A Cure celebrated its first "Pioneer Of The Year Award" with a gala event at the [[Salmagundi Club]] in New York City with more than 250 friends and supporters. Attendees were welcomed by Harold Blond, President of the Israel Children's Cancer Foundation as well as Dana Ehrlich of the [[Israeli Consulate]].
The "Pioneer Of The Year Award" was presented to [[Mira Sasson]], whose artwork and portraits were on display at the gallery. Musical performers included [[Neshama Carlebach]], [[Pharaoh's Daughter]], Adrienne Cooper and Art Bailey, [[Hasidic New Wave|Greg Wall]], [[JDub Records|Jeremiah Lockwood]], [[Masada Rock|Rashanim]], [[Dov Rosenblatt]] and many more.

revision.text:
{{See also|Audiometry}} {{more footnotes|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox diagnostic | Name = Pure tone audiometry | Image = HumanEar.jpg | Caption = Diagram of the human ear | ICD10 = | ICD9 = {{ICD9proc|95.41}} | MeshID = D001301 | OPS301 = | eMedicine_subj=article | eMedicine_topic=1822962 | OtherCodes = | }} '''Pure tone [[audiometry]]''' ('''PTA''') is the key [[hearing test]] used to identify [[Hearing (sense)|hearing]] threshold levels of an individual, enabling determination of the degree, type and configuration of a [[hearing loss]] <ref>{{eMedicine|article|1822962|Audiology Pure-Tone Testing}}</ref> and thus providing a basis for diagnosis and management. PTA is a subjective, behavioural measurement of a hearing threshold, as it relies on patient responses to [[pure tone]] stimuli. Therefore, PTA is only used on adults and children old enough to cooperate with the test procedure. As with most clinical tests, calibration of the test environment, the equipment and the stimuli to ISO standards is needed before testing proceeds. PTA only measures audibility thresholds, rather than other aspects of hearing such as [[sound localization]] and speech recognition. However, there are benefits to using PTA over other forms of hearing test, such as click [[auditory brainstem response]] (ABR). PTA provides ear specific thresholds, and uses [[frequency]] specific pure tones to give place specific responses, so that the configuration of a hearing loss can be identified. As PTA uses both air and [[bone conduction]] audiometry, the type of loss can also be identified via the [[air-bone gap]]. Although PTA has many clinical benefits, it is not perfect at identifying all losses, such as ‘dead regions’ of the cochlea and neuropathies such as [[auditory processing disorder]] (APD).<ref name="pmid15064655">{{cite journal|last1=Moore|first1=BC|title=Dead regions in the cochlea: conceptual foundations, diagnosis, and clinical applications.|journal=Ear and hearing|date=April 2004|volume=25|issue=2|pages=98–116|pmid=15064655|doi=10.1097/01.aud.0000120359.49711.d7}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Moore BCJ | year = 2001 | title = Dead Regions in the Cochlea: Diagnosis, Perceptual Consequences, and Implications for the Fitting of hearing aids | journal = Trends Amplif | volume = 5 | issue = | pages = 1–34 | doi = 10.1177/108471380100500102 | pmid=25425895 | pmc=4168936}}</ref><ref name="pmid26924453">{{cite journal|last1=Landegger|first1=LD|last2=Psaltis|first2=D|last3=Stankovic|first3=KM|title=Human audiometric thresholds do not predict specific cellular damage in the inner ear.|journal=Hearing Research|date=May 2016|volume=335|pages=83–93|doi=10.1016/j.heares.2016.02.018|pmid= 26924453}}</ref> This raises the question of whether or not [[audiogram]]s accurately predict someone’s perceived degree of disability.
== PTA procedural standards ==
There are both international and British standards regarding the PTA test protocol. [http://www.thebsa.org.uk The British Society of [[Audiology]] (BSA)] is responsible for publishing the recommended procedure for PTA, as well as many other audiological procedures. The British recommended procedure is based on international standards. Although there are some differences, the BSA-recommended procedures are in accordance with BS EN ISO 8253-1, which is the international standard for PTA established by the International Organization for Standardization. The BSA-recommended procedures provide a "best practice" test protocol for professionals to follow, increasing validity and allowing standardisation of results across Britain. The British Society of Audiology. Recommended Procedure: Pure Tone air and bone conduction threshold audiometry with and without masking and determination of uncomfortable loudness levels.<ref>The British Society of Audiology. September 2011 amended 2015. http://www.thebsa.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Pure-Tone-Audiometry-1.pdf [Accessed 13/11/2016]</ref>
== Variations ==
There are cases where conventional PTA is not an appropriate or effective method of threshold testing. Procedural changes to the conventional test method may be necessary with populations who are unable to cooperate with the test in order to obtain hearing thresholds. Sound field audiometry may be more suitable when patients are unable to wear earphones, as the stimuli are usually presented by loudspeaker. A disadvantage of this method is that although thresholds can be obtained, results are not ear specific. In addition, response to pure tone stimuli may be limited, because in a sound field pure tones create [[standing waves]], which alter [[sound intensity]] within the sound field. Therefore, it may be necessary to use other stimuli, such as [[Warble Tone|warble tones]] in sound field testing.<ref>http://www.emedicine.com/ent/topic311.htm [Accessed on 27/02/07]</ref> There are variations of conventional audiometry testing that are designed specifically for young children and infants, such as [[behavioral observation audiometry]], [[visual reinforcement audiometry]] and [[play audiometry]].<ref>http://michiganotoplasty.com/understanding-deafness-pta-testing/ [Accessed on 07/18/15].</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Hearing Testing and Screening in Young Children|url=http://www.patient.info/doctor/hearing-testing-and-screening-in-young-children|website=patient.info|accessdate=16 November 2014}}</ref>
Conventional audiometry tests frequencies between 250 [[hertz]] (Hz) and 8 kHz, whereas high frequency audiometry tests in the region of 8 kHz-16 kHz. Some environmental factors, such as [[ototoxic]] medication and noise exposure, appear to be more detrimental to high frequency sensitivity than to that of mid or low frequencies. Therefore, high frequency audiometry is an effective method of monitoring losses that are suspected to have been caused by these factors. It is also effective in detecting the auditory sensitivity changes that occur with aging.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Monteiro de Castro Silva|first1=I|last2=Feitosa|first2=MA|title=High-frequency audiometry in young and older adults when conventional audiometry is normal.|journal=Brazilian journal of otorhinolaryngology|date=2005|volume=72|issue=5|pages=665–72|doi=10.1590/S0034-72992006000500014|pmid=17221060}}</ref>
== Cross hearing and interaural attenuation == [[Image:AIR CONDUCTION.jpg|left|frame|Figure 1: Interaural attenuation with air conduction.]] [[Image:BONE CONDUCTION.jpg|frame|Figure 2: Interaural attenuation with bone conduction]]
When sound is applied to one ear the [[contralateral]] cochlea can also be stimulated to varying degrees, via vibrations through the bone of the skull. When the stimuli presented to the test ear stimulates the [[cochlea]] of the non-test ear, this is known as cross hearing. Whenever it is suspected that cross hearing has occurred it is best to use masking. This is done by temporarily elevating the threshold of the non-test ear, by presenting a masking noise at a predetermined level. This prevents the non-test ear from detecting the test signal presented to the test ear. The threshold of the test ear is measured at the same time as presenting the masking noise to the non-test ear. Thus, thresholds obtained when masking has been applied, provide an accurate representation of the true hearing threshold level of the test ear.<ref name="Katz">Katz J. Clinical Handbook of Audiology. 5th ed. Philadelphia: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins; 2002.</ref>
A reduction or loss of energy occurs with cross hearing, which is referred to as interaural attenuation (IA) or transcranial transmission loss.<ref name="Katz" /> IA varies with transducer type. It varies from 40 dB to 80 dB with supra-aural headphones. However, with insert earphones it is in the region of 55 dB. The use of insert earphones reduces the need for masking, due to the greater IA which occurs when they are used (See Figure 1).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bagatto|first1=M|last2=Moodie|first2=S|last3=Scollie|first3=S|last4=Seewald|first4=R|last5=Moodie|first5=S|last6=Pumford|first6=J|last7=Liu|first7=KP|title=Clinical protocols for hearing instrument fitting in the Desired Sensation Level method.|journal=Trends in Amplification|date=2005|volume=9|issue=4|pages=199–226|doi=10.1177/108471380500900404|pmid=16424946|pmc=4111495}}</ref>
Air conduction results in isolation, give little information regarding the type of hearing loss. When the thresholds obtained via air conduction are examined alongside those achieved with bone conduction, the configuration of the hearing loss can be determined. However, with bone conduction (performed by placing a vibrator on the [[mastoid]] bone behind the ear), both cochleas are stimulated. IA for bone conduction ranges from 0-20 dB (See Figure 2). Therefore, conventional audiometry is ear specific, with regards to both air and bone conduction audiometry, when masking is applied.
== PTA thresholds and hearing disability ==
PTA is described as the gold standard for assessment of a hearing loss <ref>Sindhusake D, Mitchell P, Smith W, Golding M, Newall P, Hartley D, et al. Validation of self-reported hearing loss. The Blue Mountains Hearing Study. Int. J. Epidemiol. 2001;30:1371-78.</ref> but how accurate PTA is at classifying the hearing loss of an individual, in terms of [[hearing impairment]] and hearing disability is open to question. Hearing impairment is defined by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) as a hearing loss with thresholds higher than 25db in one or both ears. The [[Hearing impairment#Quantification of hearing loss|degree of hearing loss]] is classified as mild, moderate, severe or profound.<ref>{{cite web|title=Deafness and hearing loss Fact sheet N°300|url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs300/en/|publisher=WHO (World Health Organization)|accessdate=16 November 2014}}</ref> The results of PTA are however a very good indicator of hearing impairment.
Hearing disability is defined by the WHO as a reduction in the ability to hear sounds in both quiet and noisy environments (compared to people with normal hearing), which is caused by a hearing impairment.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sound Advice|url=http://www.soundadviceltd.co.uk/our-services/health-surveillance-services/hearing-tests/|website=Sound Advice Safety and Health Ltd|accessdate=10 May 2016}}</ref> Several studies have investigated whether self-reported hearing problems (via questionnaires and interviews) were associated with the results from PTA. The findings of these studies indicate that in general, the results of PTA correspond to self-reported hearing problems (i.e. hearing disability). However for some individuals this is not the case; the results of PTA only, should not be used to ascertain an individual's hearing disability.<ref>Hietamen A, Era P, Henrichsen J, Rosenhall U, Sorri M, Heikkinen E. Hearing among 75-year old people in three Nordic localities: A comparative study. Int. J. Audiol. 2004;44:500-08.</ref><ref>Uchida Y, Nakashima T, Ando F, Niino N, Shimokata H. Prevalence of Self-perceived Auditory Problems and their Relation to Audiometric Thresholds in a Middle-aged to Elderly Population. Acta. Otolaryngol. 2003;123:618-26.</ref>
[[Image:Speech recognition threshold in noise2.jpg|left|thumb|500px|Figure 10: Speech recognition threshold (SRT) with noise. To aid explanation of this concept the CHL and the SNHL have the same magnitude of hearing loss (50 dBHL). The horizontal part of the curves is where the noise is inaudible. Thus, there is no masking effect on the SRT. The horizontal portion of the curve for the SNHL and CHL extends further than that for a normal hearing person, as the noise needs to become audible to become a problem. Thus, more noise has to be applied, to produce a masking effect. At the right hand side of the graph, to identify 50% of the speech correctly, the speech needs to much more intense than in the quiet. This is because at this end of the graph, the noise is very loud whether the person has a hearing loss or not. There is a transition between these two areas described. Factor A is a problem only in low noise levels, whereas Factor D is a problem when the noise level is high. ]]
Hearing impairment (based on the [[audiogram]]) and [[Hearing (sense)|auditory]] handicap (based on speech discrimination in noise) data was reviewed by Reinier Plomp {{who|date=September 2016}}. This led to the formulation of equations, which described the consequences of a hearing loss on speech intelligibility. The results of this review indicated that there were two factors of a hearing loss, which were involved in the effect on speech intelligibility. These factors were named Factor A and Factor D. Factor A affected speech intelligibility by [[attenuating]] the speech, whereas Factor D affected speech intelligibility by distorting the speech.<ref name="pmid670550">{{cite journal|last1=Plomp|first1=R|title=Auditory handicap of hearing impairment and the limited benefit of hearing aids.|journal=The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America|date=February 1978|volume=63|issue=2|pages=533–49|pmid=670550|doi=10.1121/1.381753}}</ref>
Speech recognition threshold (SRT) is defined as the [[Sound#Sound pressure level|sound pressure level]] at which 50% of the speech is identified correctly. For a person with a [[conductive hearing loss]] (CHL) in quiet, the SRT needs to be higher than for a person with normal hearing. The increase in SRT depends on the degree of hearing loss only, so Factor A reflects the audiogram of that person. In noise, the person with a CHL has the same problem as the person with normal hearing (See Figure 10).<ref name="pmid670550" />
For a person with a [[Sensorineural hearing loss]] (SNHL) in quiet, the SRT also needs to be higher than for a person with normal hearing. This is because the only factor that is important in quiet for a CHL and a SNHL is the audibility of the sound, which corresponds to Factor A. In noise, the person with a SNHL requires a better [[signal-to-noise ratio]] to achieve the same performance level, as the person with normal hearing and the person with a CHL. This shows that in noise, Factor A is not enough to explain the problems of a person with a SNHL. Therefore, there is another problem present, which is Factor D. At present, it is not known what causes Factor D. Thus, in noise the audiogram is irrelevant. It is the type of hearing loss that is important in this situation.<ref name="pmid670550" />
These findings have important implications for the design of [[hearing aids]]. As hearing aids at present can compensate for Factor A, but this is not the case for Factor D. This could be why hearing aids are not satisfactory for a lot of people.<ref name="pmid670550" /> {{clear}}
==Audiograms and hearing loss== {{main|Audiogram}} The shape of the audiogram resulting from PTA audiometry gives an indication of the type of hearing loss as well as possible causes. [[Conductive hearing loss]] due to disorders of the middle ear shows as a flat increase in thresholds across the frequency range. Sensorineural hearing loss will have a contoured shape depending on the cause. [[Presbycusis]] or age-related hearing loss for example is characterized by a high frequency roll-off (increase in thresholds). [[Noise-induced hearing loss]] has a characteristic notch at 4000 Hz. Other contours may indicate other causes for the hearing loss.
== See also == * [[Hearing range]] * [[Auditory masking]] * [[Auditory filters]] * [[Absolute threshold of hearing]] * [[Equal-loudness contours]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://www.emedicine.com/ent/topic311.htm EMedicine.com]. * [http://www.gpnotebook.co.uk/simplepage.cfm?ID=1456472077 GPNotebook.co.uk]. * [http://www.springerlink.com/content/g713573061h38g96 Springerlink.com]. * [http://www.iurc.montp.inserm.fr/cric/audition/english/start2.htm Audition Cochlea Promenade oreille ear organ Corti C.R.I.C Montpellier]. This website provides excellent diagrams and animated pictures that aid understanding of the topics covered. There are a wide range of topics covered including sound, cochlea, Organ of Corti, hair cell pathology and audiometry. * [http://www.worldaudiology.com Audiology Resources]. This site provides useful resources for people interested in audiology. * [http://www.soundadviceltd.co.uk/our-services/health-surveillance-services/hearing-tests/] This site provides excellent information regarding the Audiometric Testing procedure {{Ear tests}}
[[Category:Ear procedures]] [[Category:Audiology]] [[Category:Hearing]]

{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = | synonym = | image = File:RicketsChestXray.jpg|thumb| | image_size = | alt = | caption = Rachitic rosary on [[chest radiograph]] | pronounce = | specialty = | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} The prominent knobs of bone at the [[costochondral joint]]s of [[rickets]] patients are known as a '''rachitic rosary''' or '''beading of the ribs'''. The knobs create the appearance of large beads under the skin of the rib cage, hence the name by analogy with the beads of a Catholic Christian [[rosary]].{{cite journal|author1=John Little Morris |author2=W.F. Waugh |author3=W.C. Abbott |year=1900|title=Rickets|journal=The Alkaloidal Clinic|publisher=Clinic Publishing Company|volume=7|issue=1|language=English|quote=The earliest bone lesion that we find in incipient rickets is the beading of the ribs, the so-called rachitic rosary. This is due to an enlargement of the osteo chondric articulations, and hence its name because of fancied resemblance to the rosary used by the Catholic worshiper.}}
- {{cite web|title=Rachitic rosary|url=http://medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/rachitic+rosary|work=TheFreeDictionary|accessdate=12 August 2013}} ==Causes== Causes include:{{cite conference |editor-last=von Schulthess |editor-first=Gustav K. |title=Musculoskeletal diseases : diagnostic imaging and interventional techniques |conference=37th International Diagnostic Course in Davos (IDKD) Davos, April 2-8, 2005 : including the Pediatric Satellite course "Kangaroo" Davos, April 2-3, 2005 |year=2005 |publisher=Springer |location=Milan |isbn=8847003180 |editor2=Ch.L. Zollikofer}}
- {{cite book |editor-first=Klaus-Dietrich |editor-last=Ebel |display-editors=etal |title=Differential diagnosis in pediatric radiology |year=1999 |publisher=Thieme |location=Stuttgart |isbn=9783131081315}}
- {{cite book |editor-first=Klaus-Dietrich |editor-last=Ebel |display-editors=etal |title=Differential diagnosis in pediatric radiology |year=1999 |publisher=Thieme |location=Stuttgart |isbn=3131081317}} * Rickets : Nodularity at costochondral junction (rachitic rosary). * Scurvy : More angular costochondral junction with a sharper step-off (scorbutic rosary) and depressed sternum. * Chondrodystrophy == Pathophysiology == Rachitic rosary is due to a deficiency of calcium resulting in lack of mineralization and an overgrowth of costochondral joint cartilage. The calcium deficiency may be caused by [[Rickets]] or other causes of calcium deficiency such as [[hypoparathyroidism]]. ==Diagnosis== {{Empty section|date=December 2017}} ==Management== {{Empty section|date=December 2017}} ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.gpnotebook.co.uk/simplepage.cfm?ID=-1966079952 Entry on GP Notebook] {{Nervous and musculoskeletal system symptoms and signs}} [[Category:Pediatrics]] [[Category:Skeletal disorders]] [[Category:Malnutrition]] [[Category:Symptoms and signs: musculoskeletal system]]
